subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: President Moon Jae-in announced South Korea’s commitment to achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 during a speech at the National Assembly on October 28, 2020. Following this, the government launched a Presidential Committee on Carbon Neutrality in May 2021, consisting of representatives from the public and private sector to spearhead Korea’s long-term strategy for decarbonization. In October 2021, the committee released two scenario roadmaps for achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. The committee, which was renamed to Carbon Neutrality and Green Growth Commission under President Yoon Suk-yeol’s administration, plans to release an updated 2050 net-zero roadmap by 2023.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Korea’s latest Nationally Determined Contribution, or NDC, aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030 compared with 2018. This is an update to Korea’s previous NDC of a 24.4% reduction compared to the 2017 level. President Yoon Seok-yeol, who came into power in May 2022, vowed to maintain this target.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: South Korea plans to shut down 26 coal plants by 2036, according to a draft of the 10th Basic Plan on Electricity Supply and Demand. However, the country does not have a fully-fledged phase-out policy for fossil fuels.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: South Korea embarked on a ‘Green Growth’ strategy in 2010 under President Lee Myung-bak, aimed at stimulating the economy and securing energy independence in the long run. In 2017, President Moon Jae-in came to power and sought a more fundamental shift in Korea’s energy policy by supporting renewables and gas at the expense of coal and nuclear. In 2022, President Yoon Suk-yeol redirected Korea’s energy policy in favor of nuclear.

In August 2022, the Yoon administration released a draft of the 10th Basic Plan for Electricity Supply and Demand. According to the plan, the share of nuclear generation will rise to 33% by 2030 from 29% in 2021. The share of renewables will also increase to 22% by 2030 from just 7% in 2021. In contrast, the share of coal and gas will fall to 42% in 2030 from 62% in 2021, in accordance with Korea’s 2030 emissions reduction goal. The Korean government aims to finalize the plan by the end of 2022.

Despite moves toward a cleaner power mix, electricity generation in South Korea is currently dominated by coal (36%), which is followed by nuclear power (29%) and gas generators (26%), with renewables contributing only 7% in 2021. The government aims to increase the share of renewables to 22% by 2030.

Renewable portfolio standards (RPS), introduced in 2012 to replace the feed-in tariff program, are the primary driver of renewables installations in Korea. RPS mandates large-scale power generators to procure a government-set percentage of electricity from renewable sources. The annual RPS mandate rose to 12.5% in 2022 from 9% in 2021. The country also has an emissions trading scheme that was launched in 2015.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Korea has government-regulated fixed retail electricity rates. In 2021, electricity customers paid 7.9 US cents (109 won)/kWh for residential, 9.3 US cents (128 won)/kWh for commercial, and 7.6 US cents (105 won)/kWh for industrial rates. On the generation side, coal remains the cheapest source of power generation with the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) ranging between $55-66/MWh in 2021. The cost of building solar and wind projects in Korea is among the highest globally with LCOEs ranging between $79-148/MWh for solar and $81-152/MWh for wind. Market price distortion from subsidy (i.e. RPS), mountainous geography, and smaller average project size all contribute to Korea’s high cost of renewable energy.

subsections.title: Power market
text: The wholesale power market operates on a day-ahead, cost-based pool, in which the hourly price of electricity is determined by the variable cost of the marginal power plant. While the wholesale market is open to competition, Korea Electric Power Corp. monopolizes grid operation and the retail market.

Renewable energy power plants receive revenue from the sale of electricity on the wholesale power market as well as through the sale of renewable energy certificates. Korea Energy Agency issues 1 REC per every 1 MWh of electricity generated from renewable sources, taking into account the government-assigned REC multipliers by renewable technology. Large-scale utilities purchase RECs to meet their annual RPS requirement set by the government. The requirement obligates utilities to procure a set share of their total generation from renewable sources: 7% (2020), 9% (2021), 12.5% (2022). The government plans to raise the annual mandate to 25% by 2030.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Driven by energy-intensive manufacturing sectors such as steelmaking, automotive and electronics, South Korea’s electricity demand will likely rise until mid-2030s, opening opportunities to add new power generation capacity. Demand for renewable energy will continue to increase as the government aims to achieve 22% renewable generation by 2030 from just 7% in 2020.

To support Korean companies’ decarbonization efforts, the government also launched various procurement mechanisms related to renewable energy in 2021, including third party power purchase agreements (PPA), renewable energy certificates (REC), a green tariff, and direct investment in renewable energy. As more Korean companies commit to using clean electricity, for example by joining the RE100 initiative, corporate demand for renewable energy is also set to rise.

Opposition from local communities is one of the biggest barriers to developing power generation projects in Korea. Local communities including residents, farmers, fisheries and environmental groups often oppose power plant development, which may cause severe delays in permitting and even cancellation of projects. To address this, the government is making efforts to streamline permitting processes and provide clearer compensation guidelines for local communities, but these measures are unlikely to fully resolve the complex challenges around local community engagement.

subsections.title: EV market
text: Under President Moon, Korea accelerated support for electric vehicles (EV) and fuel cell vehicles (FCV) across all modes, while Korea’s leading automaker, Hyundai Motor Group, has also increased investment in EVs and FCVs. The Moon administration set aggressive short-term targets for EV and FCV deployment supported by purchase subsidies: the 2020 Green Mobility package aims to get 1.13 million electric vehicles on Korea’s roads supported by 45,000 charging stations (15,000 fast chargers) by 2025. For now, battery electric vehicles (BEV) and plug-in hybrids only make up 3% of the total passenger vehicle fleet but BEV sales have seen an average 89% growth rate in 2016-2020.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The country transport network is developing.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: Korea is focusing on building a resilient heating and cooling system, with special attention to seasonal hike in power demand. For that reason, it promotes gas heating and cooling and district heating through combined heat and power plants - usually fueled with gas. Most buildings are already equipped with air conditioning. Korea still relies at more than 50% on natural gas for residential space heating while supporting the expansion of district heating which already meets about 20% of demand. The use of heat pumps for space heating faces the challenge of extremely cold winters which dent efficiency and higher cost of electricity as compared to natural gas. Korea has set guidelines for energy consumption in buildings.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: There are no loans or grants available to support efficiency efforts for buildings.
